text: McNulty and Greggs attend court for Barksdale dealer Marvin Browning, unsuccessfully pressuring prosecutors for a maximum sentence to leverage him for information.
Detective Polk learns from the hospitalized Detective Mahon that Mahon will receive early retirement and an enhanced pension due to the injury sustained during the Pit raid.
Herc and Carver discover Bodie Broadus has escaped from the juvenile detention center; their subsequent raid on his home yields nothing but an embarrassed Herc apologizing to Bodie's grandmother.
Bunk and McNulty continue reviewing old homicides, searching for unsolved cases potentially linked to the Barksdale organization.
Due to Homicide unit understaffing, Sgt. Landsman assigns McNulty the seemingly unrelated cold case murder of Deirdre Kresson, noting a suspect named 'Dee'.
While investigating the Deirdre Kresson crime scene, Bunk and McNulty communicate solely using variations of 'fuck' and discover a crucial shell casing missed by previous investigators.
Sgt. Landsman defends McNulty to Major Rawls, arguing his difficult personality traits are linked to his effectiveness as a detective.
Major Rawls offers McNulty a deal: if McNulty can conclude the Barksdale detail work within two weeks, he will be allowed to return to his regular duties in Homicide.
Detective Greggs and her informant Bubbles discuss Omar Little's recent successful robbery of the Barksdale stash.
Forced to give Bubbles a ride, McNulty vents about his frustrating custody arrangement and relationship with his estranged wife, Elena.
Observing her partner Cheryl's cell phone bill, Greggs has an insight: the Barksdale crew likely uses pagers specifically to avoid creating traceable call records.
Disappointed that Dep. Comm. Burrell reports no progress on the Barksdale case, Judge Phelan contacts McNulty directly for an update.
In a meeting with Dep. Comm. Burrell, Lt. Daniels subtly indicates his willingness to pursue more advanced investigative techniques, like a wiretap, if authorized.
Greggs proposes cloning Barksdale pagers to monitor communications, but Daniels notes the immediate obstacle: they don't yet have a confirmed target pager number.
Detective Lester Freamon reveals a major breakthrough: the phone number he recovered from the wall during the Pit raid belongs to D'Angelo Barksdale's pager.
Freamon explains to McNulty that he was transferred to the obscure pawn shop unit years ago for defying orders by pursuing a politically connected suspect, warning McNulty faces a similar risk.
A drunk McNulty arrives late at Greggs' apartment, where she confirms their visual surveillance attempts failed to effectively track targets within the tower blocks.
Greggs explains McNulty's behavior to her partner Cheryl as loneliness resulting from his personal life; the two women then become intimate.
Omar Little, along with his crew members Brandon and Bailey, enjoy the profits gained from their robbery of the Barksdale stash.
Brandon apologizes for shouting Omar's name during the robbery, but Omar dismisses it, revealing his primary concern is potential retaliation against Brandon, now identified as Omar's lover.
Displaying his code, Omar gives a free vial of drugs to an addicted mother who approaches him respectfully.
Avon Barksdale discusses the stash robbery with enforcers Stinkum Artis and Wee-Bey Brice, officially putting a murder contract out on Omar and his entire crew.
Avon doubles the monetary reward for the contract on Omar's crew after Stinkum informs him that Omar is homosexual.
Stringer Bell expresses concern to Avon about the Pit's security, suspecting a potential information leak within D'Angelo's crew due to the timing of the robbery and police raid.
Stringer reassures Avon about D'Angelo's performance managing the Pit but maintains worry about a possible informant among the lower-level dealers.
Bodie Broadus unexpectedly returns to the Pit crew after escaping from juvenile detention.

Responding to Bodie's taunt about his arrest, D'Angelo Barksdale asserts his own toughness by revealing he previously murdered Deirdre Kresson, identified as Avon's former girlfriend who had threatened to inform.
Humbled by D'Angelo's claim of committing murder (something he hasn't done), Bodie's attitude towards D'Angelo shifts.
The Barksdale dealers in the low-rises proactively destroy newly installed police security cameras near the towers.
